elements.content: The reaction of Mn2+ with [Cr(ox)3]3- in the presence of the spin-crossover [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation gives rise to a 1D [Co(terpy)2][Mn(H2O)ClCr(ox)3]·H2O·0.5MeOH (1) or a 2D [Co(terpy)2][Mn(H2O)Cr(ox)3]2·5H2O·0.5MeOH (2). The trimetallic complexes display dominant ferromagnetic behavior, and spin-crossover of [Co(terpy)2]2+ is suppressed by the chemical pressure of the polymeric oxalate-bridged network.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of Mn2+ with [Cr(ox)3]3- in the presence of the spin-crossover [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation gives rise to a 1D [Co(terpy)2][Mn(H2O)ClCr(ox)3]⋅H2O⋅0.5MeOH (1) or a 2D [Co(terpy)2][Mn(H2O)Cr(ox)3]2⋅5H2O⋅0.5MeOH (2). The trimetallic complexes display dominant ferromagnetic behavior, and spin-crossover of [Co(terpy)2]2+ is suppressed by the chemical pressure of the polymeric oxalate-bridged network.

elements.content: The spin-crossover [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation has been used as a template for inducing the formation of novel 1D or 2D trimetallic CoII−MnII−CrIII(C2O4)3 species. The spin-crossover of [Co(terpy)2]2+ is not noticeable because of the large chemical force of the oxalate-bridged polymeric network.
elements.clean_text: The spin-crossover [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation has been used as a template for inducing the formation of novel 1D or 2D trimetallic CoII-MnII-CrIII(C2O4)3 species. The spin-crossover of [Co(terpy)2]2+ is not noticeable because of the large chemical force of the oxalate-bridged polymeric network.

elements.content: Molecule-based magnets derived from two paramagnetic building blocks have been shown to be potentially applied to practical use considering the exciting findings that room-temperature magnets have been achieved. Significantly, the magnetic properties can be tuned and improved by virtue of chemical control and modification. To obtain molecular magnetic materials, it is fundamental to use the bridging ligands that could effectively transmit magnetic coupling. The most popular ligands include cyanide (CN-), azide (N3 -), oxalate (ox2-), and oxo (O2- or OH-). As far as the oxalate-bridged moleculr magnets are concerned, 2D or 3D complexes of the formula cat[MIIM‘III(ox)3] (cat+ = R4N+, PPh4 +; M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu; M‘ = Cr, Fe, Ru) exhibit ferro- or ferrimagnetic ordering with the highest ordering temperature of 44 K. Interestingly, the replacement of the cat+ cation with conducting bis(ethylenedithio)tetrathiafulvalene (BEDT-TTF or ET) has given rise to the first synthetic ferromagnetic metal, and when cat+ is a photochromic N-methylated pyridospiropyran cation (SP+), the obtained complex (SP)MnCr(ox)3·H2O orders ferromagnetically at 5.5 K and exhibits crystalline-state photochromism.
elements.clean_text: Molecule-based magnets derived from two paramagnetic building blocks have been shown to be potentially applied to practical use considering the exciting findings that room-temperature magnets have been achieved. Significantly, the magnetic properties can be tuned and improved by virtue of chemical control and modification. To obtain molecular magnetic materials, it is fundamental to use the bridging ligands that could effectively transmit magnetic coupling. The most popular ligands include cyanide (CN-), azide (N3 -), oxalate (ox2-), and oxo (O2- or OH-). As far as the oxalate-bridged moleculr magnets are concerned, 2D or 3D complexes of the formula cat[MIIM‘III(ox)3] (cat+ = R4N+, PPh4 +; M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu; M‘ = Cr, Fe, Ru) exhibit ferro- or ferrimagnetic ordering with the highest ordering temperature of 44 K. Interestingly, the replacement of the cat+ cation with conducting bis(ethylenedithio)tetrathiafulvalene (BEDT-TTF or ET) has given rise to the first synthetic ferromagnetic metal, and when cat+ is a photochromic N-methylated pyridospiropyran cation (SP+), the obtained complex (SP)MnCr(ox)3⋅H2O orders ferromagnetically at 5.5 K and exhibits crystalline-state photochromism.

elements.content: Some 3d4-7 transition-metal complexes exhibit magnetic bistability (spin-crossover, SCO) at a certain temperature (T c) between high-spin and low-spin states and therefore are anticipated to be used as switching devices. Encapsulation of the SCO cations in magnetically coupled chains, sheets, or 3D anions might give rise to novel composite magnetic materials that can be used for significant investigations on cooperative (synergic) behavior. It is especially interesting to synthesize complexes with two magnetic phase transitions, for example, long-rang magnetic ordering and SCO. To this end, we prepared two novel complexes containing oxalate-bridged MnII−CrIII polymeric anions and the SCO [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation, which are reported herein. [Co(terpy)2](ClO4)2 shows gradual SCO behavior between 2E (t2g 6eg 1) and 4T1 (t2g 5eg 2) states with a transition temperature (T 1/2) of ca. 200 K, whereas the transition moves to higher temperatures when the anion is small; e.g., for [Co(terpy)2]Cl2, T 1/2 is greater than 300 K.
elements.clean_text: Some 3d4-7 transition-metal complexes exhibit magnetic bistability (spin-crossover, SCO) at a certain temperature (T c) between high-spin and low-spin states and therefore are anticipated to be used as switching devices. Encapsulation of the SCO cations in magnetically coupled chains, sheets, or 3D anions might give rise to novel composite magnetic materials that can be used for significant investigations on cooperative (synergic) behavior. It is especially interesting to synthesize complexes with two magnetic phase transitions, for example, long-rang magnetic ordering and SCO. To this end, we prepared two novel complexes containing oxalate-bridged MnII-CrIII polymeric anions and the SCO [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation, which are reported herein. [Co(terpy)2](ClO4)2 shows gradual SCO behavior between 2E (t2g 6eg 1) and 4T1 (t2g 5eg 2) states with a transition temperature  (T 1/2) of ca. 200 K, whereas the transition moves to higher temperatures when the anion is small; e.g., for [Co(terpy)2]Cl2, T 1/2 is greater than 300 K.

elements.content: The molecular structures of complexes 1 and 2 are shown in Figures and , respectively. The structure of 1 consists of a new 1D [Mn(H2O)Cl(ox)Cr(ox)2]2- anionic chain and a [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation. The anionic chain contains alternating [Mn(H2O)Cl]+ and [Cr(ox)3]3- connected by two oxalate ligands of [Cr(ox)3]3-. The Mn2+ is linked with one Cl- anion and five O atoms from two chelating ox2- bridges and one coordinating water atom. The Mn−O bond distances range from 2.160(7) to 2.341(7) Å, and the Mn−Cl bond distance is a little longer, 2.373(3) Å. As usual, the Cr3+ is coordinated by six O atoms from three oxalate ligands, with the Cr−O bond distances ranging from 1.935(6) to 2.007(6) Å. The oxalate-bridged 1D chains are hydrogen-bonded through the nonbridging oxalate O atoms and the coordinating water O atoms of adjacent chains, giving rise to a hydrogen-bonded layer (Figure , bottom). The [Co(terpy)2]2+ cations are positioned between the layers (see Figure and the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The molecular structures of complexes 1 and 2 are shown in Figures  and , respectively. The structure of 1 consists of a new 1D [Mn(H2O)Cl(ox)Cr(ox)2]2- anionic chain and a [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation. The anionic chain contains alternating [Mn(H2O)Cl]+ and [Cr(ox)3]3- connected by two oxalate ligands of [Cr(ox)3]3-. The Mn2+ is linked with one Cl- anion and five O atoms from two chelating ox2- bridges and one coordinating water atom. The Mn-O bond distances range from 2.160(7) to 2.341(7) Å, and the Mn-Cl bond distance is a little longer, 2.373(3) Å. As usual, the Cr3+ is coordinated by six O atoms from three oxalate ligands, with the Cr-O bond distances ranging from 1.935(6) to 2.007(6) Å. The oxalate-bridged 1D chains are hydrogen-bonded through the nonbridging oxalate O atoms and the coordinating water O atoms of adjacent chains, giving rise to a hydrogen-bonded layer (Figure , bottom). The [Co(terpy)2]2+ cations are positioned between the layers (see Figure  and the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Top:  structure of the oxalate-bridged anionic chain of complex1. Bottom:  hydrogen-bonded layer with [Co(terpy)2]2+ in the vicinity of the layer.
elements.clean_text: 1  Top: structure of the oxalate-bridged anionic chain of complex1. Bottom: hydrogen-bonded layer with [Co(terpy)2]2+ in the vicinity of the layer.

elements.content: Top:  connection modes of the MnII and CrIII ions in 2. Bottom:  layered structure of 2 along the c axis.
elements.clean_text: 2  Top: connection modes of the MnII and CrIII ions in 2. Bottom: layered structure of 2 along the c axis.

elements.content: The structure of complex 2 consists of a 2D oxalate-bridged layer [Mn(H2O)Cr(ox)3] n n - and a charge-balancing [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation. The 2D anionic layer contains two unique (albeit similar) Mn or two independent Cr ions connected by oxalate ligands (Figure ). The Cr ion is coordinated by six O atoms of three oxalate ligands, while the Mn ion is linked to six O atoms of two bidentate oxalate ligands, a monodentate oxalate ligand, and a water molecule. The Mn−O bond distances are in the range of 2.210(7)−2.365(9) Å. The layer consists of two different nets, large Mn4Cr4 rectangles and small Mn2Cr2 rectangles (Figure , bottom). The previously reported 2D oxalate-bridged anionic layers have the common planar honeycomb structure, and complex 2 has a unique 2D structure motif among oxalate-bridged bimetallic species. The layers are not planar but corrugated, and [Co(terpy)2]2+ cations are accommodated in the hollow of the layer and are partly embedded within the large rectangles (see the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The structure of complex 2 consists of a 2D oxalate-bridged layer [Mn(H2O)Cr(ox)3] n   n  - and a charge-balancing [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation. The 2D anionic layer contains two unique (albeit similar) Mn or two independent Cr ions connected by oxalate ligands (Figure ). The Cr ion is coordinated by six O atoms of three oxalate ligands, while the Mn ion is linked to six O atoms of two bidentate oxalate ligands, a monodentate oxalate ligand, and a water molecule. The Mn-O bond distances are in the range of 2.210(7)-2.365(9) Å. The layer consists of two different nets, large Mn4Cr4 rectangles and small Mn2Cr2 rectangles (Figure , bottom). The previously reported 2D oxalate-bridged anionic layers have the common planar honeycomb structure, and complex 2 has a unique 2D structure motif among oxalate-bridged bimetallic species. The layers are not planar but corrugated, and [Co(terpy)2]2+ cations are accommodated in the hollow of the layer and are partly embedded within the large rectangles (see the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The Co−N bond distances in the [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation range from 1.895(7) to 2.117(9) Å for 1 (173 K) and from 1.853(14) to 1.971(14) Å for 2 (113 K), corresponding to low-spin CoII at the temperatures. The Co−N bond distances in low-spin [Co(terpy)2]2+ have been shown to be in the range of 1.912−2.083 Å.
elements.clean_text: The Co-N bond distances in the [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation range from 1.895(7) to 2.117(9) Å for 1 (173 K) and from 1.853(14) to 1.971(14) Å for 2 (113 K), corresponding to low-spin CoII at the temperatures. The Co-N bond distances in low-spin [Co(terpy)2]2+ have been shown to be in the range of 1.912-2.083 Å.

elements.content: Variable-temperature direct current magnetic susceptibility data were collected on a bundle of crystals from 5 to 300 K (Figures and for complexes 1 and 2, respectively). The room-temperature χm T value (7.02 emu K mol-1) at 300 K for 1 is slightly higher than the expected spin-only value (6.625 emu K mol-1) for one MnII ion (S = 5/2), one CrIII ion (S = 3/2), and one low-spin CoII ion (S = 1/2). With a decrease of the temperature, the χm T value slightly decreases and reaches a minimum value of 6.98 emu K mol-1 at 260 K. Below 260 K, the χm T value increases, reaching a value of 15.77 emu K mol-1 at 5 K. This behavior indicates the presence of dominant ferromagnetic interactions between MnII and CrIII, which is usual for bidentately oxalate-bridged MnII−CrIII(ox)3 systems.
elements.clean_text: Variable-temperature direct current magnetic susceptibility data were collected on a bundle of crystals from 5 to 300 K (Figures  and  for complexes 1 and 2, respectively). The room-temperature χm T value (7.02 emu K mol-1) at 300 K for 1 is slightly higher than the expected spin-only value (6.625 emu K mol-1) for one MnII ion (S = 5/2), one CrIII ion (S = 3/2), and one low-spin CoII ion (S = 1/2). With a decrease of the temperature, the χm T value slightly decreases and reaches a minimum value of 6.98 emu K mol-1 at 260 K. Below 260 K, the χm T value increases, reaching a value of 15.77 emu K mol-1 at 5 K. This behavior indicates the  presence of dominant ferromagnetic interactions between MnII and CrIII, which is usual for bidentately oxalate-bridged MnII-CrIII(ox)3 systems.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of χm T for 1 in an applied field of 2 kOe. The solid line represents the best fit. Inset:  enlarged view in the temperature range of 180−300 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature dependence of χm T for 1 in an applied field of 2 kOe. The solid line represents the best fit. Inset: enlarged view in the temperature range of 180-300 K.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of χm T for 2 in an applied field of 2 kOe. The solid line represents the best fit. Inset:  model for the fitting (J ≫ |J‘|). Oxalate bridges have been shown by straight rods:  solid, bis(bidentate) bridges; hollow, bidentate/monodentate bridges.
elements.clean_text: 4  Temperature dependence of χm T for 2 in an applied field of 2 kOe. The solid line represents the best fit. Inset: model for the fitting (J ≫ |J‘|). Oxalate bridges have been shown by straight rods: solid, bis(bidentate) bridges; hollow, bidentate/monodentate bridges.

elements.content: Considering the incorporation of a possible SCO [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation, the slight increase of χm T from 260 to 300 K most likely originates from the spin transition of [Co(terpy)2]2+. To eliminate the effect of solvents, magnetic susceptibility measurements have been performed from 320 to 2 K. An increase of χm T from 260 to 320 K exists (see the Supporting Information), which should be assigned to spin transition rather than the solvent effect.
elements.clean_text: Considering the incorporation of a possible SCO [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation, the slight increase of χm T from 260 to 300 K most likely originates from the spin transition of [Co(terpy)2]2+. To eliminate the effect of solvents, magnetic susceptibility measurements have been performed from 320 to 2 K. An increase of χm T from 260 to 320 K exists (see the Supporting Information), which should be assigned to spin transition rather than the solvent effect.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility of complex 1 can be fitted to the equation (see the Supporting Information) based on the Hamiltonian Ĥ = − J Ŝ i suitable for the 1D Heisenberg alternating spin systems. The contribution of [Co(terpy)2]2+ was considered as constant in the form of χm T = Ng 2β2 S(S + 1)/3k, where S = 1/2 for low-spin CoII. The fit to the magnetic data in the temperature range of 5−260 K gave the parameters J = 1.18(1) cm-1, g = g Mn = g Cr = g Co = 2.03(1), and zJ‘ = −0.038(1) cm-1. The inclusion of zJ‘ accounts for the interchain magnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibility of complex 1 can be fitted to the equation (see the Supporting Information) based on the Hamiltonian Ĥ = -   J Ŝ  i     suitable for the 1D Heisenberg alternating spin systems. The contribution of [Co(terpy)2]2+ was considered as constant in the form of χm T = Ng 2β2 S(S + 1)/3k, where S = 1/2 for low-spin CoII. The fit to the magnetic data in the temperature range of 5-260 K gave the parameters J = 1.18(1) cm-1, g = g Mn = g Cr = g Co = 2.03(1), and zJ‘ = -0.038(1) cm-1. The inclusion of zJ‘ accounts for the interchain magnetic coupling.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility of complex 2 is a little different. Although a similar global ferromagnetic interaction is present, the absence of a minimum in the χm T−T curve suggests no spin transition of [Co(terpy)2]2+ (Figure ). The room-temperature χm T value of 12.4 emu K mol-1 is consistent with the spin-only theoretical value of 12.875 emu K mol-1 assuming that CoII is low-spin.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibility of complex 2 is a little different. Although a similar global ferromagnetic interaction is present, the absence of a minimum in the χm T-T curve suggests no spin transition of [Co(terpy)2]2+ (Figure ). The room-temperature χm T value of 12.4 emu K mol-1 is consistent with the spin-only theoretical value of 12.875 emu K mol-1 assuming that CoII is low-spin.

elements.content: Alternatively, the layer (Figure , bottom) can be regarded as bidentate oxalated-bridged (toward Mn) MnII−CrIII chains linked by monodentate oxalate bridges (toward Mn), as illustrated in the inset of Figure . From the magnetic viewpoint, the former pathway usually transmits a ferromagnetic MnII−CrIII coupling while the latter transfers an antiferromagnetic MnII−CrIII interaction. Considering that the former is much stronger than the latter, the oxalate-bridged layer can be thought of as weakly antiferromagnetically coupled chains. Therefore, a mean-field approach (see the Supporting Information) can be used with the model shown in the inset of Figure . The best fit to the magnetic susceptibilities of 2 in the whole temperature range gave the parameters J = 2.47(1) cm-1, g = g Mn = g Cr = g Co = 2.03(1), and zJ‘ = −0.35(1) cm-1. The J values for complexes 1 and 2 are close to those for bis(bidentate) oxalate-bridged MnII−CrIII complexes. Field-cooled magnetization (FCM) of 2 shows the absence of 3D magnetic ordering down to 2 K possibly because of the presence of monodentate oxalate bridges in the 2D layer.
elements.clean_text: Alternatively, the layer (Figure , bottom) can be regarded as bidentate oxalated-bridged (toward Mn) MnII-CrIII chains linked by monodentate oxalate bridges (toward Mn), as illustrated in the inset of Figure . From the magnetic viewpoint, the former pathway usually transmits a ferromagnetic MnII-CrIII coupling while the latter transfers an antiferromagnetic MnII-CrIII interaction. Considering that the former is much stronger than the latter, the oxalate-bridged layer can be thought of as weakly antiferromagnetically coupled chains. Therefore, a mean-field approach (see the Supporting Information) can be used with the model shown in the inset of Figure . The best fit to the magnetic susceptibilities of 2 in the whole temperature range gave the parameters J = 2.47(1) cm-1, g = g Mn = g Cr = g Co = 2.03(1), and zJ‘ = -0.35(1) cm-1. The J values for complexes 1 and 2 are close to those for bis(bidentate) oxalate-bridged MnII-CrIII complexes. Field-cooled magnetization (FCM) of 2 shows the absence of 3D magnetic ordering down to 2 K possibly because of the presence of monodentate oxalate bridges in the 2D layer.

elements.content: In summary, we have shown that the SCO [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation can be integrated in oxalate-bridged MnII−CrIII(ox)3 polymeric anions. The SCO behavior of [Co(terpy)2]2+ strongly depends on the chemical pressure of the polymeric anions:  the transition moves to higher temperature when the [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation is incorporated between coordination bond-connected layers. This indicates that a hydrogen-bonded layered network gives weaker chemical pressure compared with the strong coordination bond-connected 2D network. A novel oxalate-bridged bimetallic 2D layer and a 1D chain structure are formed in the presence of the [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation. Further studies on the synthesis of analogues taking advantage of the chemical pressure to tune the SCO behavior are in progress.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have shown that the SCO [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation can be integrated in oxalate-bridged MnII-CrIII(ox)3 polymeric anions. The SCO behavior of [Co(terpy)2]2+ strongly depends on the chemical pressure of the polymeric anions: the transition moves to higher temperature when the [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation is incorporated between coordination bond-connected layers. This indicates that a hydrogen-bonded layered network gives weaker chemical pressure compared with the strong coordination bond-connected 2D network. A novel oxalate-bridged bimetallic 2D layer and a 1D chain structure are formed in the presence of the [Co(terpy)2]2+ cation. Further studies on the synthesis of analogues taking advantage of the chemical pressure to tune the SCO behavior are in progress.

elements.content: Cell packing diagrams of 1 and 2, FCM plots for 1 and 2, χm T−T plot measured from 320 to 2 K, magnetic fitting equations, and an X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

Cell packing diagrams of 1 and 2, FCM plots for 1 and 2, χm T-T plot measured from 320 to 2 K, magnetic fitting equations, and an X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: Variable-temperature direct current magnetic susceptibility data were collected on a bundle of crystals from 5 to 300 K (Figures and for complexes 1 and 2, respectively). The room-temperature χm T value (7.02 emu K mol-1) at 300 K for 1 is slightly higher than the expected spin-only value (6.625 emu K mol-1) for one MnII ion (S = 5/2), one CrIII ion (S = 3/2), and one low-spin CoII ion (S = 1/2). With a decrease of the temperature, the χm T value slightly decreases and reaches a minimum value of 6.98 emu K mol-1 at 260 K. Below 260 K, the χm T value increases, reaching a value of 15.77 emu K mol-1 at 5 K. This behavior indicates the presence of dominant ferromagnetic interactions between MnII and CrIII, which is usual for bidentately oxalate-bridged MnII−CrIII(ox)3 systems.

With a decrease of the temperature, the χm T value slightly decreases and reaches a minimum value of 6.98 emu K mol-1 at 260 K. Below 260 K, the χm T value increases, reaching a value of 15.77 emu K mol-1 at 5 K. This behavior indicates the  presence of dominant ferromagnetic interactions between MnII and CrIII, which is usual for bidentately oxalate-bridged MnII-CrIII(ox)3 systems.

metadata.title:
New Oxalate-Bridged CrIII−MnII Polymeric Network Incorporating a
Spin-Crossover [Co(terpy)2]2+ Cation
